Both environmental complexity and Survive & Reproduce are aspects that have=
 for at least a decade been explored and written about (core wars, polyworl=
d...). For this reason I think that "novelty search" is not really novel, t=
he best it can achieve is to be like Survive & Reproduce fitness function. =
What is meant by Survive & Reproduce in this context, is that the organism =
itself is responsible for its reproductive cycle, like in polyworld for exa=
mple, as opposed to a fitness function directly...

Regards,
-Gene

--- On =
Tue, 4/5/11, Colin Green <colin.green1@...> wrote:

From: Colin Green=
 <colin.green1@...>
Subject: Re: [neat] "Survive and Reproduce" as an=
 Objective
To: neat@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tuesday, April 5, 2011, 11:55 PM
=







=C2=A0



  


    
      
      
      Hi Ken,



On 4 April 2011 2=
1:40, Ken <kstanley@...> wrote:

>

> Colin, I wanted to branch m=
y response to you to a new thread because I want to focus

> on the idea th=
at "survive and reproduce" is an objective. This is not really an argument
=

> with anything you said, but mainly a commentary on the meaning of "objec=
tive" that I

> think draws a useful distinction.



I'm not sure I agree w=
ith the spirit of your argument but it's just a

gut feeling at this point =
so I'll have a go at clarifying my thoughts

a bit further and maybe I can =
home in a bit more on where I'm

disagreeing (if at all).



By 'survive' I=
 mean - execute some strategy that results in survival.

So find food and s=
helter, avoid danger, etc. Good survival strategy

for the domain =3D> good=
 chance of surviving, bad strategy =3D> lower

chance.



In an EA that sur=
vival *strategy* is 'do well on the fitness metric'

(aka objective) - beca=
use the only way to survive is to get selected

by the EA's selection crite=
ria. So I think we can clarify the argument

by drawing a distinction betwe=
en surviving/reproducing and

/strategies/ that lead to surviving and repro=
ducing. I think perhaps

we (or I) have conflated the two. Survive/reproduc=
e is the high level

[implicit] objective that is always present, and survi=
val /strategy/

is what we normally refer to as objective or goal in EC.


=

So far there's no distinction between nature/biology and EC. To my

mind n=
ature has found complex /strategies/ for survival because:



A) Vastly mor=
e computational resource (or equivalent) [per unit time].

B) Vastly more t=
ime.

C) Vastly more complex domain.



It's this latter point that I feel =
has tended to be overlooked. If you

consider every living thing alive toda=
y and trace back through all of

their ancestors, then every single one of =
those zillions of organisms

executed a successful strategy that lead to su=
rvival. Considerably

more organisms not on that family tree didn't survive=
 - so the natural

world does try out unsuccessful strategies, but only for=
 one

generation at a time, it doesn't create offspring with variations on
=

those poor strategies in the hope of finding something better. What

does =
happen though is that stragies are so complex (for creatures with

large br=
ains anyway) that they can incorporate successful parts (find

food) and ye=
t waste much time on poor sub-strategies (effectively

stragey efficiency).=
 Evolution will select for efficiency but unlike

survival it's not a binar=
y yes/no thing, it's more probabilistic, so

more like the small low scorin=
g species in NEAT (from fitness

sharing).



It's perhaps those poor side =
strategies that fit your idea of

searching with no objective, they piggy b=
ack on for the ride and very

occasionally become useful. Where EC tends to=
 fall short IMO is that

the domain complexity is vastly lower than the nat=
ural world so

there's less opportunty for exploring variations in strategy=
 -

branching off into multiple successful branches and sub-branches

witho=
ut a major loss in fitness on the objective. Put another way, the

natural =
world's fitness landscape is dominated by smooth undulations

in all dimens=
ions, whereas EC objectives tend to have a few

sharp/steep local maxima.

=


Nature also provides a gentle selection pressure towards complex

strateg=
ies by providing resources that require increasingly complex

strategies to=
 reach - you can't eat those land plants until you evolve

legs ang lungs. =
And you can't eat those omnivores without evolving

good eyes and fast/stro=
ng muscles, etc. but the plants and meat were

there as an untapped resourc=
e until that first legged creature and

first carnivore came along. So we c=
an see now that framing the

survival as being an objective that's been ach=
ieved on day one misses

a lot of the key dynamics that drive evolution. Su=
rviving is the high

level implicit objective, some species have not moved =
on from floating

in the sea eatign CO2 and sunlight, but other strategies =
were evolved

to tap into new previously untapped resources - and that clim=
b from

simple to complex resources utilisation continues to this day.



C=
olin.
